fields.description:
When an external DNS server attempts to resolve an {{A}} record recursively against the Eucalyptus DNS server it is possible for an intermediate {{NS}} record to have a {{target name}} which does not have a valid {{A}} record available.  When such a record is cached upstream subsequent DNS resolutions will fail.

Using the ECC install here is the breakdown of an example lookup of {{euca-173-205-188-106.eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com}} (just some instance A record).

h4. Recursive DNS look up trace
Using {{dig +trace}} shows the sequence of {{NS}} lookups that lead to the DNS server hosting the actual {{A}} record.  

I've trimmed the output for brevity but made sure that the relevant {{NS}} servers which are traversed are preserved in the output.
{code}[root@community-frontend ~]# dig @8.8.8.8 euca-173-205-188-106.eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com +trace{code}

h5. NS for {{.}} is global DNS stuff
{code}
.			2290	IN	NS	d.root-servers.net.
;; SNIP MULTIPLES: we use 'd.root-servers.net' in the next step
;; Received 228 bytes from 8.8.8.8#53(8.8.8.8) in 45 ms
{code}

h5. NS for {{com.}} is still global DNS stuff
{code}
com.			172800	IN	NS	i.gtld-servers.net.
;; SNIP MULTIPLES:  we use 'i.gtld-servers.net' in the next step
;; Received 500 bytes from 199.7.91.13#53(199.7.91.13) in 80 ms
;; NOTE: Response from d.root-servers.net => 13.91.7.199.in-addr.arpa
{code}

h5. NS for {{eucalyptus.com.}} is our host for our domain
{code}
eucalyptus.com.		172800	IN	NS	ns33.domaincontrol.com.
eucalyptus.com.		172800	IN	NS	ns34.domaincontrol.com.
;; Received 152 bytes from 192.43.172.30#53(192.43.172.30) in 160 ms
;; NOTE: Response from i.gtld-servers.net => 30.172.43.192.in-addr.arpa
{code}

h5. NS for {{ecc.eucalyptus.com.}} is the subdomain delegation to Eucalyptus
{code}
ecc.eucalyptus.com.	1800	IN	NS	community-frontend.eucalyptus.com.
;; Received 117 bytes from 216.69.185.17#53(216.69.185.17) in 12 ms
;; NOTE: Response from ns33.domaincontrol.com => 17.185.69.216.in-addr.arpa
{code}

h5. NS for {{eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com.}} is a nested subdomain w/in Eucalyptus
{code}
euca-173-205-188-106.eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com. 604800 IN A	173.205.188.106
eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com. 604800 IN NS	community-frontend.eucalyptus.com.ecc.eucalyptus.com.
;; Received 148 bytes from 173.205.188.7#53(173.205.188.7) in 65 ms
;; NOTE: Response from community-frontend.eucalyptus.com => 7.188.205.173.in-addr.arpa	
{code}

h4. Things get wierd
In the above {{NS}} response for {{eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com}} things get wierd.
# The response is referencing an unqualified {{NS}} record (missing {{A}} record in ADDITIONAL section)
# The {{NS}} doesn't even have an {{A}} record
# That {{NS}} record looks like it has a nonesense target **ANYWAY**.

h5. What goes wrong
* A /well behaved/ (in the sense of this bug) server will never cache the bogus {{NS}} record and will always work.
* A /misbehaving/ will, starting with a clean cache:
** Successfully respond to an uncached recursive request *one time*
** The response will have the bogus {{NS}} record
** The server then caches the bogus {{NS}} record as its part of an authoritative response
** *NOW* subsequent recursive queries for in the subdomain get the longest matching suffix against the bogus {{NS}} record
** Attempt to contact the bogus {{NS}} server but fail to lookup its nonexistant {{A}} record

h5. DNS Caching
The {{NS}} record will be in the cache of the recursing DNS server for a limited period of time. During that time queries will /continue to succeed for previously cached records/.  Then, when the {{NS}} record expires from the cache, the subsequent request will succeed (adding a new {{A}} record perhaps) but also bringing back in the {{NS}} record.
RESULT:  Seemingly non-deterministic behaviour.  Time sensitive behaviour.  This is exaggeratted in DNS servers which have some kind of load balancing.

h5. Seeing the issue
Using {{dnstracer}} it is easy to see the difference between a "good" and "bad" recursive query exchange.  The following output shows the "good" output on the left and the "bad" on the right.  The output has been trimmed for brevity.
* "good": {{dnstracer -v -q a euca-173-205-188-106.eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com -s 216.69.185.17}}
* "bad":  {{dnstracer -v -q a euca-173-205-188-106.eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com -s 10.80.90.1}}
{code}
[root@community-frontend ~]# diff -U1 dns.good dns.bad 
--- dns.good	2013-06-15 18:37:24.031002779 -0700
+++ dns.bad	2013-06-15 18:37:18.151910636 -0700
@@ -1,6 +1,6 @@
-Tracing to euca-173-205-188-106.eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com[a] via 216.69.185.17, maximum of 3 retries
+Tracing to euca-173-205-188-106.eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com[a] via 10.80.90.1, maximum of 3 retries
-216.69.185.17 (216.69.185.17) IP HEADER
+10.80.90.1 (10.80.90.1) IP HEADER
-- Destination address:  216.69.185.17
+- Destination address:  10.80.90.1
@@ -17,4 +17,4 @@
 DNS HEADER (recv)
-- Flags:                0x8000 (R )
+- Flags:                0x8080 (R RA )
@@ -33,10 +33,10 @@
-- Resource data:        (18)community-frontend(10)eucalyptus(3)com
+- Resource data:        (18)community-frontend(10)eucalyptus(3)com(3)ecc(10)eucalyptus(3)com
 ADDITIONAL RR
-- Domainname:           (18)community-frontend(10)eucalyptus(3)com
+- Domainname:           (18)community-frontend(10)eucalyptus(3)com(3)ecc(10)eucalyptus(3)com
@@ -44,6 +44,6 @@ 
-  \___ community-frontend.eucalyptus.com [ecc.eucalyptus.com] (173.205.188.7) IP HEADER
+  \___ community-frontend.eucalyptus.com.ecc.eucalyptus.com [ecc.eucalyptus.com] (No IP address)
{code}
fields.summary: DNS responds with an invalid NS record under certain conditions

comments.body:
The attachment is a workaround which works against {{3.3.0}}.  The script can be run in a cron job.  The execution is indicated below:
{code}
# euca-modify-property -f euca=./EUCA-6546.groovy 
PROPERTY	euca	[
eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com.=>eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com.	604800	IN	SOA	root.eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com. community-frontend.eucalyptus.com.eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com. 1 86400 604800 2419200 600
eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com.	604800	IN	NS	community-frontend.eucalyptus.com.eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com.
community-frontend.eucalyptus.com.eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com.	60	IN	A	173.205.188.7

, 
ecc.eucalyptus.com.=>ecc.eucalyptus.com.	604800	IN	SOA	root.ecc.eucalyptus.com. community-frontend.eucalyptus.com.ecc.eucalyptus.com. 1 86400 604800 2419200 600
ecc.eucalyptus.com.	604800	IN	NS	community-frontend.eucalyptus.com.ecc.eucalyptus.com.
community-frontend.eucalyptus.com.ecc.eucalyptus.com.	60	IN	A	173.205.188.7

, 
eucalyptus.internal.=>eucalyptus.internal.	604800	IN	SOA	root.eucalyptus.internal. community-frontend.eucalyptus.com.eucalyptus.internal. 1 86400 604800 2419200 600
eucalyptus.internal.	604800	IN	NS	community-frontend.eucalyptus.com.eucalyptus.internal.
community-frontend.eucalyptus.com.eucalyptus.internal.	60	IN	A	173.205.188.7

] was executed successfully.
{code}

The output shows the final outcome of the 3 zones.  The *important thing* is that the target of each {{NS}} record (right hand side) have a corresponding {{A}} record for the {{NS}} target.

[~decker] is this behavior seen when enabling the experimental DNS parts? Or in general in 3.3.0?

Also, are we supposed to have the NS t be also the nested name, ie community-frontend.eucalyptus.com.eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com? Wouldn't be community-frontend.eucalyptus.com be sufficient?

[~graziano]:
# This has to do with the old DNS code which regressed between 3.2.0 and 3.3.0 in this subtle way.
# Indeed the bug here is that the way the NS records are being created is arbitrary (and, clearly in this case, nonsense).  Fiddling w/ the workaround is *not* the right fix to this problem, but is available immediately.  In the end, the {{NS}} records returned should always correspond w/ the availability ordered set of DNS services we run -- and these have a permanent name, e.g., {{ns1.yoursub.domain.com}} which resolves to the host which runs correspondingly indexed (topologically) DNS service.

[~hspencer] [~decker]

Where do we stand on this one? How do we verify? Im confused. Please provide clear steps to reproduce the problem identified in the title of this bug.

[~viglesias] and [~decker],

IMO, the bug is around the SOA record (which is an invalid nameserver if you can't look it up).  You should be able to resolve the [SOA record|http://www.zytrax.com/books/dns/ch8/soa.html] name-server.  For example, when doing a lookup from the instance for the nameserver in the SOA record, here is what I see on my 3.3.2 cloud:

{code}
ubuntu@euca-172-17-113-149:~$ dig money.eucalyptus.euca-hasp.eucalyptus-systems.com @10.104.1.216

; <<>> DiG 9.9.2-P1 <<>> money.eucalyptus.euca-hasp.eucalyptus-systems.com @10.104.1.216
;; global options: +cmd
;; Got answer:
;; ->>HEADER<<- opcode: QUERY, status: ?51, id: 49920
;; flags: qr aa rd; QUERY: 1, ANSWER: 0, AUTHORITY: 1, ADDITIONAL: 1
;; WARNING: recursion requested but not available

;; OPT PSEUDOSECTION:
; EDNS: version: 0, flags:; udp: 4096
;; QUESTION SECTION:
;money.eucalyptus.euca-hasp.eucalyptus-systems.com. IN A

;; AUTHORITY SECTION:
eucalyptus.euca-hasp.eucalyptus-systems.com. 604800 IN SOA root.eucalyptus.euca-hasp.eucalyptus-systems.com. odc-d-06-07.prc.eucalyptus-systems.com.eucalyptus.euca-hasp.eucalyptus-systems.com. 1 86400 604800 2419200 600

;; Query time: 16 msec
;; SERVER: 10.104.1.216#53(10.104.1.216)
;; WHEN: Wed Oct 16 19:25:16 2013
;; MSG SIZE  rcvd: 158

ubuntu@euca-172-17-113-149:~$ nslookup root.eucalyptus.euca-hasp.eucalyptus-systems.com 10.104.1.216
Server:		10.104.1.216
Address:	10.104.1.216#53

** server can't find root.eucalyptus.euca-hasp.eucalyptus-systems.com: NXDOMAIN

ubuntu@euca-172-17-113-149:~$ nslookup root.eucalyptus.euca-hasp.eucalyptus-systems.com
Server:		8.8.8.8
Address:	8.8.8.8#53

** server can't find root.eucalyptus.euca-hasp.eucalyptus-systems.com: NXDOMAIN
{code}

*Steps*

* Set up a Eucalyptus 3.3.2 Cloud
* Enable Eucalyptus DNS
* Launch an instance and make sure /etc/resolv.conf contains the CLC IP address (system.dns.nameserveraddress cloud property)
* SSH into the instance and do a lookup on an DNS name that would fall under the domain that the cloud is fully delegated to use.
* Whatever name server shows up in the SOA record, attempt to resolve that.  It should be resolvable.

Let me know if you need any additional information.

[~viglesias] can you elaborate?  {{euca-describe-properties}} for the relevant {{dns}} and {{subdomain}} properties.  Also, the {{dig}} command and output which produces the failure.  Please and thanks.

Tried to reproduced using our QA system and another DNS server as well and couldn't reproduce this case.

{noformat}
root@euca-1-117-100-173:~# dig euca-10-111-101-142.eucalyptus.c-20.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com @10.111.1.55

; <<>> DiG 9.8.1-P1 <<>> euca-10-111-101-142.eucalyptus.c-20.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com @10.111.1.55
;; global options: +cmd
;; Got answer:
;; ->>HEADER<<- opcode: QUERY, status: NOERROR, id: 43573
;; flags: qr aa rd ra; QUERY: 1, ANSWER: 1, AUTHORITY: 0, ADDITIONAL: 0

;; QUESTION SECTION:
;euca-10-111-101-142.eucalyptus.c-20.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com. IN A

;; ANSWER SECTION:
euca-10-111-101-142.eucalyptus.c-20.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com. 60 IN A 1.117.100.173

;; Query time: 58 msec
;; SERVER: 10.111.1.55#53(10.111.1.55)
;; WHEN: Fri Feb 28 19:18:33 2014
;; MSG SIZE  rcvd: 103






root@euca-1-117-100-173:~# dig euca-10-111-101-142.eucalyptus.c-20.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com @10.1.1.254

; <<>> DiG 9.8.1-P1 <<>> euca-10-111-101-142.eucalyptus.c-20.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com @10.1.1.254
;; global options: +cmd
;; Got answer:
;; ->>HEADER<<- opcode: QUERY, status: NOERROR, id: 26364
;; flags: qr rd ra; QUERY: 1, ANSWER: 1, AUTHORITY: 1, ADDITIONAL: 1

;; QUESTION SECTION:
;euca-10-111-101-142.eucalyptus.c-20.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com. IN A

;; ANSWER SECTION:
euca-10-111-101-142.eucalyptus.c-20.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com. 60 IN A 10.111.101.142

;; AUTHORITY SECTION:
c-20.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com.	0 IN NS	c-20.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com.

;; ADDITIONAL SECTION:
c-20.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com. 10800 IN A	10.111.1.55

;; Query time: 156 msec
;; SERVER: 10.1.1.254#53(10.1.1.254)
;; WHEN: Fri Feb 28 19:18:38 2014
;; MSG SIZE  rcvd: 138




root@euca-1-117-100-173:~# nslookup c-20.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com
Server:		10.1.1.254
Address:	10.1.1.254#53

Name:	c-20.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com
Address: 10.111.1.55

root@euca-1-117-100-173:~# 
{noformat}
